article.headline: California 64, UCLA 51
article.story: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Hard to believe UCLA could be surprised by much on a basketball court, considering the Bruins' tradition. California found a way, though. David Paris scored a career-high 20 points and Cal's zone stymied UCLA in a 64-51 victory Saturday that snapped a four-game losing streak at Pauley Pavilion, where the crowd booed the Bruins. The Golden Bears (9-8, 2-5 Pac-10) came in as the conference's worst team, but they looked stellar against UCLA's horrible defense. They also ended an overall four-game skid. "This was one of the best wins we've had," said Paris, who scored most of his points under the basket. "We were really hungry after four losses." Cal's zone forced the Bruins into shooting a season-worst 30 percent from the field. "Just caught us by surprise and I don't think we practiced it for a while," senior Dijon Thompson said. "They were playing big, shotblocking and really attacked us." The Bruins (10-6, 4-4) lost their third straight and second in a row at Pauley. For the second consecutive game, they fell behind in the first half (15 points) and never made a run in the second. The same thing happened in a 75-64 loss to Stanford on Thursday. "We just didn't come out to play at all and it showed," said freshman Jordan Farmar, who couldn't explain the Bruins' lack of fire. "I'm very disappointed in our effort." Paris has quickly become one of the most improved players in the Pac-10 after starting the season with a career average of 1.6 points. He topped his career high of 16 points set against UC Riverside in the season opener. Paris was 10-of-11 from the floor, and is 15-of-17 in his last two games. "David takes the ball to the basket hard," Cal coach Ben Braun said. "He's had better practices lately and the other players have more confidence in him." The Bears finally held on to a second-half lead after blowing their leads in six of eight losses, including at Southern California on Thursday. It was their first win at Pauley since 2000. Rod Benson added 14 points and a career-high 14 rebounds for Cal. "It's the first game we played 40 minutes with no letdowns," Paris said. "We should never lose four in a row." The Bears were without Richard Midgley, who sat out both games in Los Angeles after spraining his right shoulder at Washington on Jan. 2. "It was a huge win for our team, especially being short-handed," Braun said. "We're obviously a better team with Richard Midgley in the lineup." With four minutes remaining, fans emptied out of Pauley and into the warm sunshine, leaving behind the gloom of an ugly loss. UCLA's point total was a season-low; the Bruins' previous worst was 64 points against Stanford. It also was the lowest total scored against Cal in Pauley since a 51-47 victory in 1975. Their 18 first-half points also were a season-low. "We just couldn't hit any shots," Farmar said. "We were tentative and couldn't get in the flow. We have to stay together and play for each other and play with a passion and intensity." The Bruins all wore white headbands, but that was the only unity they displayed. Even when the Bruins capitalized on a Cal turnover, they botched it. Thompson promptly threw the ball away on the other end, and Cal ended up scoring. UCLA never got closer than nine points early in the second half. Michael Fey led the Bruins in scoring for the second straight game with 12 points, and Arron Afflalo added 10. Thompson tied his season-low of six points set Thursday. "Just didn't get the job done," Thompson said. "We played hard and with the intent to do the best we can, just came up short." Brian Morrison scored inside to draw the Bruins to 39-30. Cal used a 19-7 run, including eight points by Dominic McGuire and six by Paris, to take its largest lead, 58-37 with 7:18 to play. The Bruins scored just four baskets in the final 6:58 -- and three of them came in the final minute, making the game appear closer than it was. In the first half, freshman Josh Shipp scored off Morrison's miss to tie the game at 10. Then the Bears took over, outscoring the Bruins 23-8 to end the half ahead 33-18. UCLA went about nine minutes without a field goal until Thompson scored his first of the game during Cal's run. Fans booed the Bruins as they left the court at halftime. The Bruins shot 23 percent from the floor in the half, while Cal shot 45 percent and controlled the boards, 27-16.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
